com.scpi.parser

Class SCPIParser

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.scpi.parser.SCPIParser

  • public class SCPIParser
extends java.lang.Object
    The SCPIParser is a general purpose command parser for SCPI-style commands. Refer to Standard Commands for Programmable Instruments on Wikipedia for more information about SCPI.

    Usage

    To the SCPIParser class can be used in two ways. First, you can use the class as-is by calling addHandler to add handlers to SCPIParser objects.

    The preferred usage is to extend the SCPIParser class and register handlers in the constructor of the extending class. New handlers are registered by calling the addHandler method and specifying the full, unabbreviated SCPI command path and an SCPIParser.SCPICommandHandler. Command handlers must implement the SCPIParser.SCPICommandHandler functional interface. For example,

    Example Usage

      class SimpleSCPIParser extends SCPIParser {
    public SimpleSCPIParser() {
      addHandler("*IDN?", this::IDN);
    }

    String IDN(String[] args) {
          return "Simple SCPI Parser";
    }
 }

 SimpleSCPIParser myParser = new SimpleSCPIParser();
 for (String result : myParser.accept("*IDN?")) {
   System.out.println(result);
 }

    The parser will correctly interpret chained commands of the form *IDN?;MEAS:VOLT:DC?;AC?. In this case, three commands would be processed, where the final command MEAS:VOLT:AC? would be correctly interpreted.

    Performance Considerations

    By default, the SCPIParser caches getCacheSizeLimit() number of queries, greatly speeding execution of repeated queries (default is 20). This optimizes performance when the parser accepts many identical queries. (Only the parsed version of queries is cached. Results are computed for each call to accept(String query).)

    Commands containing argument values are not cached by default. (For example, queries that send data to the parser.) This prevents caching queries that are not expected to be repeated often. However, if only a small number of queries containing identical argument values can be expected, then caching can be enabled by calling setCacheQueriesWithArguments(true).

      Base class for SCPI-related exceptions
      class  SCPIParser.SCPIMissingHandlerException
      An exception that may be raised while parsing a malformed-query, or query that refers to an undefined command.

    • Method Detail

      • addHandler

        public void addHandler(java.lang.String path,
                       SCPIParser.SCPICommandHandler handler)
        Adds a SCPICommandHandler for a specified SCPI path.
        Parameters:
        path - an absolute SCPI path
        handler - the method to associate with the path

      • accept

        public java.lang.String[] accept(java.lang.String query)
                          throws SCPIParser.SCPIMissingHandlerException
        Accepts query input and returns the results of query processing. Each element in the query is returned as a string, or null if no result was returned by the handler.
        Parameters:
        query - a string containing input to the parser
        Returns:
        returns an array containing the result of each command contained in the query (may contain null)
        Throws:
        SCPIParser.SCPIMissingHandlerException - this exception may be thrown if the query refers to an unmapped function or contains an error. The caller should handle this exception.

      • setCacheQueriesWithArguments

        public void setCacheQueriesWithArguments(boolean newValue)
        If set to true, then queries containing argument values will be cached. This can negatively impact performance if many unique queries are sent to the parser.
        Parameters:
        newValue - desired caching state for queries that contain arguments.

      • isCacheQueriesWithArguments

        public boolean isCacheQueriesWithArguments()
        Returns:
        the current state of the caching queries containing arguments.

      • setCacheSizeLimit

        public void setCacheSizeLimit(int newSize)
        Sets the desired cache size limit (number of unique queries). Setting the size to 0 will effectively disable caching. Negative values are interpreted as 0.
        Parameters:
        newSize - the desired cache size

      • getCacheSizeLimit

        public int getCacheSizeLimit()
        Returns:
        current cache size limit
